issue.title: Configuration: How about having a fallback default configuration instead of global overrides?
issue.body:
_This issue might be tangentially related to prior discussion about configuration files in issue #145._

Rocket looks amazing, and it improves a lot on other web frameworks I have used. I am really eager to use it for some of my own personal projects, as well as to tell my coworkers about it. :slightly_smiling_face: 

However, while reading the getting started guide, one thing surprised and confused me: The way configuration files are currently (Rocket v. 0.2.6) set up (relevant Documentation section: https://rocket.rs/guide/overview/#configuration).

Right now, a `Rocket.toml` file has a section per environment. It seems that these environments are hard-coded to be `development`, `staging` and `production`. Furthermore, there is a `global` section.

What I had expected would be that common settings could be stored in the global section, which could then be overridden by the environment-specific sections. However, instead, changes in the global section take precedence over the environment-specific settings.

What is the reason behind this design choice? I have frequently come across situations where many configuration settings of an application are shared across environments (especially database-related, CPU-related and external-API-related settings are shared between at least the production and staging environments), with a few (e.g. hostname, email-sending settings, logging settings) being overridden per environment.

The inverse, where I wanted to override settings that are specific to each environment by one setting in the 'global' section never arose. It seems like a weird, implicit type of behaviour where part of earlier-provided configuration settings are discarded.

So, my question: What is the reason behind the current way the 'global' configuration environment section works? Is it too late to invert the way this works?

_(A backwards-compatible solution would be to have a 'defaults' section that contains configuration settings that take the least precedence, which are then overridden by each of the environment-specific sections, which might then be overridden by an 'overrides' section, with 'global' being a deprecated alias for 'overrides'.)_

issue.title: Question: How to set raw vector array of certs to TLS config instead of path
issue.body:
Version : 0.3.14
Operating System : Mac
Hi,
I am using this module to build an HTTPS server for a microservice and I want to set certificates and keys using a raw vector array instead of certs path as I require to keep the certificates and keys away from running container. As far as I have gone through the documentation the `set_tls` function takes only paths. So how can I set them using vector array??
Thanks in advance

issue.title: TLS files must exist in all environments for rocket to load

labels.name: deficiency
labels.description: Something doesn't work as well as it could

issue.body:
I have a website in Rocket (using v0.3.6, latest at writing). I am developing on my laptop (Mac OS X 10.12.6 (the development environment) and releasing on Amazon Linux 2017.12. The bug happens in both places

That is, in my Rocket.rs, I have defined TLS to key/cert for my development environment to /etc/ssl/<files>, whereas on Amazon Linux I am using letsencrypt, so the keys are in /etc/letsencrypt/...

If I set one global.tls and set the keys in the same location in both, there is no issue. However, I would like the keys in different locations for different environments. When I do this, I get the following error launching:

Error: I/O error while setting tls.certs:
    => No such file or directory (os error 2)

This happens with both
ROCKET_ENV=dev <exe> 
and
ROCKET_ENV=prod <exe>

On their respective machines. I believe the bug exists because:

https://github.com/SergioBenitez/Rocket/blob/master/lib/src/config/builder.rs#L307 
Calls set_tls which inside
https://github.com/SergioBenitez/Rocket/blob/master/lib/src/config/config.rs#L505
Returns the error here because the TLS file is not found

However, it should only do this on the environment that is actually executing

Please let me know if I am missing something here

issue.title: [Feature Request] Make `RocketConfig::parse` public
issue.body:
... or something similar for the `rocket::config::Config` struct like:

 - Deriving/implementing `Deserialize` for `rocket::config::Config` 
 - Moving the parsing method to `rocket::config::Config` and making it public

## Why you believe this feature is necessary and use case

I am trying to implement a Rocket application with additional configuration options. Currently, the `Config` struct only supports a simple key-value store for extra configuration options. That is fine.

As an alternative, I am implementing a separate configuration structure that will be deserialized from another JSON/TOML file. 

I would like to allow users to specify the filename for this additional `JSON/TOML` file as one of the extra configuration options in `Rocket.toml`. This file can be, and should probably be, different for the three rocket environments.

Then, I would like to parse `Rocket.toml` with the same rules that Rocket does, and extract this extra value BEFORE I `launch` Rocket so that I can deserialize the JSON/TOML file and then add the struct into Rocket as to be `manage`d. 

This is not really do-able at the moment, or even to implement for myself because  `rocket::config::Config`  does not derive `Deserialize`. Alternative, I would have to essentially duplicate quite a bit of code to achieve this.

body:
#551 linked here. I'd also very much like to load TLS keys & certificates from a string or byte array, continuing the path from https://github.com/SergioBenitez/Rocket/issues/809

Is there a reason Rocket uses rustls? I'd prefer to use a more mature TLS library that is configurable. For example, `native-tls` through `hyper-native-tls`. That way you could pass a `native_tls::TlsAcceptor` to the Rocket config builder.

issue.title: Need a way to prevent credentials in config from showing up on start up
issue.body:
## Feature request

Currently if any credential is loaded with `Rocket::config`, it will be printed in plain text at the start up. It is quite uncommon to treat logs as confidential data, so I'd think it'd be better to be masked, or don't show up at al, to prevent the leak of passwords.

For now, `rocket_conrib::database` seems to be the number one victim as almost all database require some form of password. 

For implementation, I'd propose to add a function to `Config` to mark the configuration keys with confidential information. e.g.

```rust
// At command line: ROCKET_DB_PASS=foobar cargo run
let mut config = /* ... */
config.set_as_credential("db_pass");
```

issue.title: [Feature Request] unhide `config::RocketConfig`

labels.name: duplicate
labels.description: This issue or pull request already exists

issue.body:
I want to be able to re-use my `Rocket.toml` for some helper cli apps to support my server. I'd like to re-use the parsing and env detection infrastructure (i.e. I'd like to be able to call [`RocketConfig::read`]). I'm currently just using it even though it's hidden, but I'm worried its considered an implementation detail that might change.

Would you consider unhiding it and making semver guarantees?

The doc(hidden) is at [core/lib/src/config/mod.rs#L224].

[`RocketConfig::read`]: https://github.com/SergioBenitez/Rocket/blob/master/core/lib/src/config/mod.rs#L234
[core/lib/src/config/mod.rs#L224]: https://github.com/SergioBenitez/Rocket/blob/master/core/lib/src/config/mod.rs#L224

issue.title: No `secret_key` is configured

labels.name: no bug
labels.description: The reported bug was confirmed nonexistent

issue.body:
Hello I'm running `Rocket v0.4.0` I'm trying to use it in production environment so when I generate a binary with `cargo build --release` normally it should switch Rocket to `prod` mode I guess, and when I run the server I have this in the logs 
```
Configured for production.
    => address: 0.0.0.0
    => port: 8000
    => log: critical
    => workers: 8
    => secret key: generated
    => limits: forms = 32KiB
    => keep-alive: 5s
    => tls: disabled
Warning: environment is 'production', but no `secret_key` is configured
 Rocket has launched from http://0.0.0.0:8000
```

Knowing that I already set `secret_key` in `Rocket.toml` file with a different port for production, so I feel like the `Rocket.toml` is not used here, that's said if I run the application without building it using `ROCKET_ENV=prod cargo run` it uses the `Rocket.toml` configuration, so I'm wondering if I need to add something during the release build?

issue.title: What do we think of separate configuration files / general configuration improvements?
issue.body:
I see that I can do what I want with `rocket::custom` but I'm wondering if @SergioBenitez and contributors would like this as well (as its still definitely early enough to change).

At a high level, what I would want is to be able to have N configuration files (a default and 1 per environment), instead of a single configuration file. Some reasons for this:
 - Looking at [Rails](https://github.com/railsconfig/config) and [Django](https://medium.com/@ayarshabeer/django-best-practice-settings-file-for-multiple-environments-6d71c6966ee2#.m254m0pp9), it seems this kind of idea is widely used
 - Production/Staging configuration could be [encrypted](https://www.agwa.name/projects/git-crypt/) or generated from environment variables inside of Docker startup script
 - Most configuration options I can imagine apply to all environments with just some tweaking per environment (which is why something like `config/default.toml` is a useful concept.

We can support this a few ways (that I can see):
 - Allow specifying relative-from-cwd globs of configuration files.. `with_config("config/*.toml")` or `with_config("Rocket.toml", "Rocket.production.toml")`. This could default to `"Rocket.toml"` to keep compatibility.
 - Allow specifying a configuration path.. `with_config("config")`. This wouldn't be able to be defaulted to `.` as it would then pick up `Cargo.toml`.

My vote is for 2 (config path) and default it to `config`.

The actual format of the files (environment tables) can stay the same or environment can be taken from the filename. I'd prefer the former as it'd be more flexible.

Some more things of interest to configuration (but can be tackled later):
 - Ability to pull configuration from environment
 - Ability to pull configuration from etcd (or similar services)

---

Another note is that a (12-factor) configuration library would be of general use to Rust and would probably be best served as a crate that is then used by Rocket. I don't mind jumping on that if come to a consensus here. Just help me come up with a name. `config` is taken by an unfinished/unmaintained `libconfig` parser (maybe we can ask @filipegoncalves to rename it to `libconfig` or ask crates.io if unresponsive). 

---

For reference I *really* like how https://github.com/lorenwest/node-config just _works_.

issue.title: No direct API to always get a config value as a string
issue.body:
I was initially going to file this as a bug report but then realized it fits more as a feature request.

This is on `Rocket 0.4.0`, on `Mac OS X 10.13.6 (17G3025)`

I'm trying to write a configuration where a user provides an app ID (which can be alphanumeric). This is used to make external API calls. I have code like this in my app:

```
let _test = rocket.config().get_string("test").expect("Need this to be set!");
```

This works fine if the value of the appropriate environment variable is a string:

```
$ ROCKET_TEST='abc' cargo run
```

But if I pass it in as an integer (albeit within quotes on the shell), this will fail:

```
ROCKET_TEST='123' cargo run
thread 'main' panicked at 'Need this to be set!: BadType("development.test", "a string", "integer", Some("[redacted]/Rocket.toml"))', src/libcore/result.rs:997:5
```

I know that this is documented, but this makes generic development hard. The external API works with both numeric only and alpha IDs (I don't control this). If the value they provide in the config happens to just be numeric, the code will fail.

I believe this is the line of code which forces it to always be parsed as an integer: 

https://github.com/SergioBenitez/Rocket/blob/v0.4/core/lib/src/config/toml_ext.rs#L64

I'm currently using this workaround:

```
let _test = format!("{}", rocket.config().get_extra("test").expect("Need this to be set!"));
```

That works, but it was not obvious at all.

Is it possible to provide an API to get the raw string value, regardless of the type?

issue.title: Stable version
issue.body:
Hello, where I work all the frameworks and libraries must have a stable version.  Is there a date for the release of stable version 1.0?

Thanks.

issue.title: Clean shutdown?
issue.body:
Is there any way to perform a "clean" shutdown of Rocket, such that any requests currently being handled can finish (and such that managed state can be cleanly dropped)? I'm assuming right now that pressing ^C just kills the program without any graceful shutdown, since I would expect Rocket to print something to stdout otherwise.

Besides not wanting to have a bad experience for users, I'm primarily concerned with the fact that the program I'm writing is using SQLite and therefore killing it abruptly in the middle of any database mutations is probably a bad idea.

issue.title: `[extras]` logging on launch exposes DB credentials in URL

labels.name: duplicate
labels.description: This issue or pull request already exists

issue.body:
Hello!

> The version of Rocket you're using. Ensure it's the latest, if possible.

```toml
rocket = "0.4.2"
rocket_contrib = { version = "0.4.2", features = ["diesel_postgres_pool"] }
```

> The operating system (distribution and version) where the issue occurs.

```
$ cat /etc/issue
Debian GNU/Linux 9 \n \l
```

> A brief description of the bug that includes:

On launch of a rocket application there is logging of configuration details. One of those details is the `[extras]` field, if set. The code [here](https://github.com/SergioBenitez/Rocket/blob/4e6a7ddd5fffe66185baade28b421b7e6a46c70d/core/lib/src/rocket.rs#L424-L428) and [here](https://github.com/SergioBenitez/Rocket/blob/4e6a7ddd5fffe66185baade28b421b7e6a46c70d/core/lib/src/logger.rs#L110) seems to show that it will be printed even on the `Critical` logging level.

When this logs it is exposing the URL for connecting to our database, but [by convention](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/10/libpq-connect.html) ("33.1.1.2. Connection URIs") this contains the password to the database. 

> How you uncovered the bug. Short, reproducible tests are especially useful.

1. Set `Config(...).build(env).extras("database", DATABASE_MAP)` prior to `launch`ing Rocket   
2. Run the application in production mode and look at logs on stdout or whatever sink is configured

> Ideas, if any, about what Rocket is doing incorrectly.

Rocket ought not to log anything out on launch for `[extras]` for production as it potentially contains sensitive information, or Rocket ought to provide a simple way to mark values for hiding.

issue.title: TOML value parsing on parameters passed by environment
issue.body:
When passing a dictionary (inline table in TOML's terminology) by environment in certain ways, I get behaviours that can be confusing at times:

```
ROCKET_EXAMPLE="{str=test}" cargo run
```

gives `example: { str = "test " }`, the same as

```
ROCKET_EXAMPLE="{str="test" }" cargo run
```

because this way the shell interprets that the quotes aren't nested and passes the concatenation of the strings, while the way to get correct behaviour seems to be to escape quotes inside the table:

```
ROCKET_EXAMPLE="{str=\"test\" }" cargo run
```

Maybe there should be a warning when parsing a value that is not a number or another value that doesn't require quotes? As far as I can tell from TOML's specification, this is not contemplated.

body: I came across the same issue and created a small launcher script that might be interesting for others: https://github.com/rethab/rocket-launcher What it allows you to do is define placeholders in your Rocket.toml and have them replaced by environment variables at startup.

issue.title: Add ability to override path to Rocket.toml configuration file.

labels.name: pr: closed
labels.description: This pull request was not merged

issue.body:
Right now a single Rocket.toml is allowed with a limited amount of environments. This change allows an environment variable, ROCKET_CONFIG_FILE to be set, allowing a user to override environment details with additional configuration files.

This will alleviate some of the concerns in #852.

issue.title: Overriding Nested Parameters
issue.body:
This is a question, but it might turn into a feature request. I'm currently using rocket_oauth2, which recommends the following configuration in `Rocket.toml`

```
[global.oauth.google]
provider = "Google"
client_id = "<client_id>"
client_secret = "<client_secret>"
redirect_uri = "http://localhost:8000/auth/google"
```

Obviously, it's not a good idea to commit `client_id` and `client_secret` to git, so I would like to override these with environment variables. I've tried the following environment variables, to no clear effect.

`ROCKET_CLIENT_ID`, `ROCKET_OAUTH_GOOGLE_CLIENT_ID`. 

Is there an environment variables that would make this work, or should this be a feature request?

## Mandatory Details

  1. The version of Rocket this question is based on, if any.

0.4.2, should apply to all versions though.

  2. What steps you've taken to answer the question yourself.

Read the source in question, tried every combination of environment variable that I can think of.

  3. What documentation you believe should include an answer to this question.

[These Docs](https://api.rocket.rs/v0.4/rocket/config/index.html) should be updated to cover this use case.

body:
Per my comment in #1233, I'd like to request the ability to override deeply nested configuration parameters via environment variables. This would allow for relatively complex configuration structures in `.toml` files, while keeping sensitive details out of git. The current recommendation of embedding TOML into environment variables is ... cumbersome.

I can see two means to accomplish this:

1. Override environment variables based on path
2. Indicate environment variables _in_ toml

1 would involve allowing variables like `ROCKET_FOO_BAR_BAZ` to change the configuration key `foo.bar.baz`. It has the advantage of simplicity, but there is some risk of key collisions. If a configuration file has the the keys `foo_bar_baz` and `foo.bar.baz`, there can be some confusion about which key should be overridden.

2 would involve modifying the TOML structure to indicate which keys can be overridden by which environment variables. I'd recommend shamelessly copying [yesod`s](https://github.com/yesodweb/yesod/wiki/Configuration) rather clever scheme.

issue.title: Implement compression for the async version

labels.name: pr: closed
labels.description: This pull request was not merged

issue.body:
I started off a new small project where I'm using the async branch and noticed that the compression feature is not ported over yet.

So I ported it to use `async-compression` which also gives a much nicer interface to the brotli de-/encoder.

Currently `async-compression` doesn't natively support the `AsyncRead` of `tokio` yet, so I needed to add `tokio-util` as a bridge between the `tokio` and `futures` crates.

The re-enabled tests all pass but I didn't do any manual testing so far.

issue.title: Launching multiple rockets on the same port does not report an error.

labels.name: deficiency
labels.description: Something doesn't work as well as it could

issue.body:
To begin with, thank you for this project! The documentation and introduction is fantastic.

I tried to start two processes of the hello world example and expected the second one to fail with some error like "Address already in use" but instead the second process reports success on the same hostname and port as the first process.

I looked through the code for rocket 0.2.0 and hyper 0.10.4 but did not find the problem. When instead trying std::net::TcpListener I do get the expected error.
